case_vignette: An 8-year-old male presents with 1 week of itchy blisters on the ears! He just recently returned from spring break with his family! He denies using any particular products on the ears before the rash! He says that this has occurred yearly for the last several years, always around the same time! He denies proximal muscle weakness! He denies flaking in the scalp!
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have itchy blisters on my ears that have been there for a week.
Have you noticed similar blisters anywhere else on your body?
No, the blisters are only on my ears.
Do you have any known allergies or have you had any recent exposure to new products or environments?
I haven't used any particular products on my ears before the rash, and this issue seems to happen every year around the same time.
Do you have any existing medical conditions or are you currently taking any medications?
No, I don't have any existing medical conditions or medications.
Is there a history of skin conditions or allergies in your family?
I'm not aware of any family history of skin conditions or allergies.
Final Diagnosis: Seasonal allergic contact dermatitis

The patient hasn't applied any specific products to their ears prior to the development of the rash. This condition seems to recur annually around the same time. The patient has no known existing medical conditions or medications. Additionally, there is no known family history of skin conditions or allergies.
trial_0.summarized_frq: Allergic contact dermatitis possibly due to a seasonal allergen.
